WJHU Awarded Funds for National Program
by Tom McNamara
The National Endowment
for the Arts, a federal agency
has announced a fundmatching award of $100,000 to
WJHU for the production of
"Anerican Radio Showcase."
This will consist of a series of
documentary programs which
could be aired as early as the
fall of 1987.
David Creagh, general
manager of the station, expects
the series to be more successful
than previous attempts at
presenting a coherent national
program of this kind. He explained that producers of this
type of material have been
prevented from doing experimental work by financial
constraints. Organizations
which commission documentary work often pay very little
in view of the amount of time
required to produce an original
program. In addition, these
organizations often demand to
be granted all rights to the work
in perpetuity, while only broadcasting it a few times, after
which time the tape "sits on the
shelf," said Creagh.
The programs to be aired will

either be funded entirely by
WJHU or completed with funding from the station. The station will make its facilities for
turning "raw tape" into finished programs available to the
shows' producers; Creagh
described the station as "one of
the best facilities in the counfor

production" work. According
to Creagh, the station will not
be "buying anything off the
shelf"—all work to be included will be new.
One group of documentaries
which will likely be included in
the series is "American Landscapes," produced by Jay
Allison and Larry Massett. The
show is in production now on
the Mississippi River, and a
Grand Canyon "sound portrait" is scheduled to be taped
in November. Allison and
Massett are among the most
prolific producers for "All
Things Considered," an evening news program carried by
about 300 stations and reaching
an audience of approximately
10 million listeners.

and mentioned that a producer

abortion, from the first

quite rich," Creagh said. "It
can delve much more deeply
than a 5-minute television
interview.
"We will really redefine what

a CBS television program." He
said that some episodes of
"American Radio Showcase"

others will be much softer in

get beyond the surface of the
subject.

Students React as Capital Ups Drinking Age
by Kim Lankford
The District of Columbia's
City Council passed a measure
on Wednesday, September 24,
that would raise the drinking
age for beer and wine to 21 in
the nation's capital, which is
the last haven for 18-, 19-, and
20-year-old Hopkins students
who wish to drink legally. The
legal age to purchase hard liquor was previously established at 21.
The 10-3 vote was cast in
light of two recent highway
fatalities involving young people from Maryland driving into D.C. to drink in the
Georgetown area. The federal
government had also threatened to block payment of ten
percent of the District's

highway funds if such a
measure was not approved.
The council called its action
which went into effect on October 1 and is subject to a 30-day
period of review by Congress
an "emergency measure." The
council is required to pass final
legislation within 90 days.
The version which was passed
would include a grandfather's
clause, which would insure that
anyone who currently has the
privilege to drink legally would
not have that revoked.
However, according to the
September 25 Sun, Charles A.

pressure on the council to
modify the legislation to restrict
the grandfather's clause to
D.C. residents only.

George Fisher, dean of the
School of Arts and Sciences,
commented, "My overall impression is one of deep dismay
that students have been arrested
and a determination to find a
more constructive way of dealing with conflict, one more appropriate to the University
environment."
"I haven't met anyone who
was with the administration on
this one," added Professor
David Harvey of the Department of Geography and Environmental Engineering. "I
think the Coalition's won a
splendid victory."
Coalition member Paul
Genest said that Muller promised the Coalition a decision by
4 p.m. today on whether a new
shanty would be permitted on
campus.

Shanty is Erected
The idea for building the
shanty was hatched Sunday
evening when fifty people, most
of whom were Hopkins students, participated in a
Coalition-sponsored "sleepout" on divestment in front of
Shriver Hall.
A majority of the Coalition
members present at the vigil
voted to build a shanty and defend it if Hopkins security were
to attempt to remove it. This
proposal defeated two others
that would have permitted a
Coalition-built shanty to be
torn down.
Bond said that early Monday
morning, the wood used for the
shanty, dubbed "Son of Shanty" by the Coalition, was
secretly brought onto campus
"under security's eyes" and
was stored in Ames Hall.
"We put the pieces in Ames
and then dropped them over the
ledge," said Bond, referring to
the stairs between Rowland and
Ames. When the trustees arrived at 11 a.m. they were greeted

by the sight of posters, including one large banner hung
on the pediment of Shriver
Hall, and "nets" made of yarn
which covered many of the benches and trees on the lower
quads. One security guard stationed outside of Shriver Hall
during the trustees' meeting
described the trustees' arrival as
"pretty orderly" without incident from Coalition members.
At 11:45 a.m. the Coalition
members had a scheduled
meeting with the investment
committee and presented their
opinions on divestment.
According to Fisher, who
was present at the meeting,
"the finance committee of the
Trustees had a good talk with
the Coalition this morning. It is
the beginning of a very constructive dialogue, the kind of
dialogue that we'd like to see
more of."
After the trustees broke for
lunch, the Coalition erected the
shanty. According to Bond, the
hammering went unnoticed
because, "everyone must have
thought it was normal construction. It was all very exciting,"
added Bond.
The roofless shanty was built
on the lower quad and made
from remnants of the former
shanties, including the one that
was firebombed. It was constructed quickly, according to
Michael Johns.
In an interview Wednesday,
Fisher said, "Making a decision
to erect a shanty within a few
hours [of the meeting] was
premature. The trustees could
not possibly have reacted in a
substative way within that time
period and to them, the act of
erecting a shanty under those
circumstances could seem
strongly confrontational."
Even some people who supported the Coalition felt that
the shanty was limiting their
negotiating power. Richard
Cone, a professor of the
biophysics department, who
acted as liaison between Jakie
Hall and the Coalition warned
the Coalition that the "strong

possibility" of having a meeting
with the administration would
not materialize "if the shanty
doesn't come down."
It was Cone, along with
David Harvey of the geography
and environmental engineering
department, and Emily Martin
of the anthropology department that ran back and forth
throughout the day shuttling
news between Hall and the
Coalition. Cone reported to the
Coalition at 3 p.m. with news
that, "Jakie said that Steve is
in a real bind since the Board
told him to have the injunction
and most of them are here."
Also relayed by Cone was the
message that "Jakie reported
that no arrests will be made until six." Added Cone, "Steve
was the one who authorized
it."
While the Coaliton debated
on what plan of action to take,
the security department started
to gear up for the impending
confrontation. At 2:30 p.m.
Larkin came to take photographs of the shanty and those
around it, saying only, "No
comments from me other than
I'm just following orders."
The Coalition debate was
also interrupted at this time by
graduate student Stanley Lippmann who tried to break-up the
meeting by constantly aiming
insults at individual members
and the Coaliton as a whole.
"I think it's a big cop-out,"
yelled Lippmann, "You can't
face me, you need a shack."
Requests for him to sit down
and listen by Coalition
members were ignored as he
added "We're not here on earth
to listen to animals talk."
Most of the afternoon went
without incident until 4:30 p.m.
when Fishbein appeared with
four show of cause notices for
Bond, Holly Flood, Johns, and
Jonathan Lewis. The notices require them to appear in court
and face charges of contempt
of court for building the shanty while the injunction banning
unauthorized structures was in
effect.

Fishbein remarked, "the
shanty has no right to be here.
We have no intention of removing students. The University his
no ol4jection to students
assembling, but the shanty will
come down."
Asked why only four Coalition members were faced with
charges, Johns said, "they
picked us out simply because
we're visible symbols of the
Coalition."
The show cause order was
postponed on Wednesday,
along with the hearing on the
extended injuction banning
"unauthorized structures,"
originally scheduled for October 6,
Coalition member Michael
Johns said, "As I understand
it, it was Estelle Fishbein who
first asked for a postponement."
Johns added that the Coalition's counsel, Michael Berlin
asserted that Judge Joseph
H.H. Kaplan "would probably
look on us unfavorably for not
accepting a postponement."

Fourteen are Arrested

As the 6 p.m. deadline for
removing the shanty drew near,
roughly 250 people had massed on the Lower Quad, including crews from three local
television news teams and a
small group of D.U. brothers
sitting in chairs and wearing
straw hats.
Fisher said of these D.U.
members, "They clearly had a
right to observe the events, but
in view of the despicable way in
which some of the D.U.
brothers treated the original
shanty, it was in bad taste for
that D.U. group to stand as a
distinct contingent apart from
the rest of the campus
community."
Weathering catcalls from
people like graduate student
Stanley Lippmann, who called
the protesters "passive idiots,"
fourteen protesters tied themselves to the shanty, singing
"We Shall Overcome" with the
nearly fifty others who sat with
them.
The fourteen had signed an
arrest list earlier in the day to
indicate their willingness to be

During the past several years, the
quality of the Milton S. Eisenhower
Symposium has oscillated dramatically,
Happily, M.S.E. Symposium '86 entitled Religion and Politics: The Separation
of Church and State, is apparently continuing the swing toward improvement
that characterized the planning of last
year's series,
This year the Symposium, which was
founded by students twenty-seven years
ago in honor of former University President Milton S. Eisenhower, will feature
two nationally prominent figures wellknown for their positions with respect to
church/state issues, namely Pat Robertson and John Cardinal O'Connor. Three
lesser known but equally interesting
speakers will complete the line-up.
Considering the financial limitations
of the Symposium and the relatively
small audiences it can hope to attract, the
acquisition of at least two well-known
speakers is certainly an accomplishment
for M.S.E. Symposiufn Co-Chairmen,
Zeid Raad and Paul Carliner. But
perhaps their greater accomplishment
has been the careful selection of a wellbalanced range of speakers.
Last November when the church/state

topic was chosen and Zeid Raad, a
member of the Jordanian royal family,
was picked to be a co-chairman, a storm
of controversy broke out. Some critics
agrued that the Symposium might
become a forum for anti-Israeli propaganda. Even a cursory glance at the
list of the speakers and their topics for
this symposium reveals that those fears
were groundless.
The three keynote Shriver lecturers
this year represent each of the three principal religious denominations in this
country. Furthermore, the two Garrett
Room Seminars (a new addition to the
Symposium this year) will focus on fundamentalism using Islam and Judaism as
case studies. The balance overall is
commendable.
No Symposium can hope to address
completely the range of issues suggested
by its topic, particularly when the topic
is as broad as the separation of church
and state. The best any Symposium can.
do is to treat all sides of its topic evenhandedly.
This year, with such a well-balanced
range of symposium speakers, the
Hopkins community can applaud Raad
and Carliner for a job well done.

A Shameful Day
Monday, September 28 was a
shameful day for Hopkins indeed.
For the first time in the history of this
institution, students were arrested for
peaceful demonstration. As Homewood
administrators looked on, a contingent
of security forces dragged fourteen prodivestment protestors off to jail and
demolished a protest shanty erected on
the lower quad that day.
Monday's clash was an ugly
skirmish—the kind of conflict no one
wants to witness. Fortunately, a decision
made at an emergency meeting of the Executuve Committee of the Board of
Trustees late last night will likely prevent
the kind of unsavory confrontation that
occu red Monday from happening in the
future.
According to the late-breaking decision (which comes on the eve of the
Coalition's newest scheduled shanty construction project) the Coalition will be
allowed to build a shanty or shanties on
the lower quad provided that the structures meet applicable fire and safety
regulations and that no one inhabits
them.
We applaud that decision.
The issue which has divided the Coalition and the administration all along can
be traced to a conflict between two
specific sets of concerns. On the one
hand, the Coalition has maintained that
its members have a right to protest the
University's divestment policy. For the
Coalition, the physical safety of protesters has always been a secondary
concern.

The administration, however, has insisted continually that safety must come
first and foremost. According to the administration, matters of safety can
outweigh freedom of speech concerns.
Both sides have made very legitimate
arguments. Strangely enough, both sides
also seem to have been in fundamental
agreement all along concerning the importance of freedom of expression and
safety. The only area of difference, until now, has been the priority that should
be given to the two sets of concerns.
With so much in common, it's surprising that the Coalition and the administration couldn't have reached a cordial settlement on the issue of shanty
construction earlier. All along, the administration simply should have allowed demonstrators to build protest shanties provided the shanties were structurally safe.
The Coalition members for their part
should have publically committed
themselves to paying scrupulous attention to fire and safety laws.
This morning, an impending sequel to
Monday's ignoble events seems to have
been averted. Reason has apparently
triumphed over the brute force tactics used earlier this week.
We can only hope that the latest decision to permit the construction of safe
protest shanties will foreshadow a
climate of cooperation between protestors and the University and prevent
unnecessary and mutually unproductive
hostilities in the future.

Student Council meeting last
Wednesday as reported by the

SAC Executive Board have

posters for private use to one
bulletin board on campus until

position of the Board that

at the Board meeting, it was
never voted upon or approved.

policy, as passed by the SAC
Executive Board and Student

clearly marked expiration date.

with thumbtacks or tape, not
staples.

assessed for each illegal poster.

are not on bulletin boards and
excessive postering on a bulletin
board. The money collected
will go into a fund for purchasing new bulletin boards.

any confusion about the poster
policy. Any suggestions for improving the policy is more than
welcome by the SAC Executive
Board.

Topic of Council Discussion
by Adil Al-Shab
Though last on the agenda,
the issue of South Africa raised the most discussion and
tempers at the meeting of the
Student
this
Council
Wednesday.
Most of the debate centered
on how the Council should attempt to handle the situation
rather than actually make decisions on possible policies.
Junior Class Representative
Ken Kimura asked the Council,
"Do we have a legitimate right
to talk about this?"
Personal reactions to Monday's events dominated the
discussion. "The shanty was
just sitting on the quad, but
now that they've got attention
[the Coalition] is going
bananas," said Housing Chairman Ken Hansen. "If we just
ignore them maybe they will go
away."
Some students thought it improper for the Council to
discuss a political issue. Chris
Verica, the senior class president commented, "We're
elected as council members, not
republicans, democrats, conservatives, or liberals. I think
we're getting a little cocky if we
put our opinions where they
don't belong."
Susan Land, a sophomore
class representative, saw the
debate as one that focused on
the issue of freedom of speech.
"The Coalition had the right to
put up the shanty originally,
but now it seems like just an ugly thing," she said. "If they
have the right to see the shanty, we have the right not to have
to see the shanty. It's our
freedom of speech."
Damien Doute, a junior class
representative, rebutted Land's
statement, saying, "Ugly things
are ugly things; you can't make
them beautiful."
After an hour of debate,
Kimura suggested that he
develop a questionnaire to
gauge students' beliefs on the
issue. Together with Buildings
and Grounds Chairman Jim
Finnerty's suggestion that the

Council foster public debate on
the issue, the suggestion of a
questionnaire convinced the
Council to close debate on the
issue for the evening.

During the past several years, the
quality of the Milton S. Eisenhower
Symposium has oscillated dramatically,
Happily, M.S.E. Symposium '86 entitled Religion and Politics: The Separation
of Church and State, is apparently continuing the swing toward improvement
that characterized the planning of last
year's series,
This year the Symposium, which was
founded by students twenty-seven years
ago in honor of former University President Milton S. Eisenhower, will feature
two nationally prominent figures wellknown for their positions with respect to
church/state issues, namely Pat Robertson and John Cardinal O'Connor. Three
lesser known but equally interesting
speakers will complete the line-up.
Considering the financial limitations
of the Symposium and the relatively
small audiences it can hope to attract, the
acquisition of at least two well-known
speakers is certainly an accomplishment
for M.S.E. Symposiufn Co-Chairmen,
Zeid Raad and Paul Carliner. But
perhaps their greater accomplishment
has been the careful selection of a wellbalanced range of speakers.
Last November when the church/state

topic was chosen and Zeid Raad, a
member of the Jordanian royal family,
was picked to be a co-chairman, a storm
of controversy broke out. Some critics
agrued that the Symposium might
become a forum for anti-Israeli propaganda. Even a cursory glance at the
list of the speakers and their topics for
this symposium reveals that those fears
were groundless.
The three keynote Shriver lecturers
this year represent each of the three principal religious denominations in this
country. Furthermore, the two Garrett
Room Seminars (a new addition to the
Symposium this year) will focus on fundamentalism using Islam and Judaism as
case studies. The balance overall is
commendable.
No Symposium can hope to address
completely the range of issues suggested
by its topic, particularly when the topic
is as broad as the separation of church
and state. The best any Symposium can.
do is to treat all sides of its topic evenhandedly.
This year, with such a well-balanced
range of symposium speakers, the
Hopkins community can applaud Raad
and Carliner for a job well done.

A Shameful Day
Monday, September 28 was a
shameful day for Hopkins indeed.
For the first time in the history of this
institution, students were arrested for
peaceful demonstration. As Homewood
administrators looked on, a contingent
of security forces dragged fourteen prodivestment protestors off to jail and
demolished a protest shanty erected on
the lower quad that day.
Monday's clash was an ugly
skirmish—the kind of conflict no one
wants to witness. Fortunately, a decision
made at an emergency meeting of the Executuve Committee of the Board of
Trustees late last night will likely prevent
the kind of unsavory confrontation that
occu red Monday from happening in the
future.
According to the late-breaking decision (which comes on the eve of the
Coalition's newest scheduled shanty construction project) the Coalition will be
allowed to build a shanty or shanties on
the lower quad provided that the structures meet applicable fire and safety
regulations and that no one inhabits
them.
We applaud that decision.
The issue which has divided the Coalition and the administration all along can
be traced to a conflict between two
specific sets of concerns. On the one
hand, the Coalition has maintained that
its members have a right to protest the
University's divestment policy. For the
Coalition, the physical safety of protesters has always been a secondary
concern.

The administration, however, has insisted continually that safety must come
first and foremost. According to the administration, matters of safety can
outweigh freedom of speech concerns.
Both sides have made very legitimate
arguments. Strangely enough, both sides
also seem to have been in fundamental
agreement all along concerning the importance of freedom of expression and
safety. The only area of difference, until now, has been the priority that should
be given to the two sets of concerns.
With so much in common, it's surprising that the Coalition and the administration couldn't have reached a cordial settlement on the issue of shanty
construction earlier. All along, the administration simply should have allowed demonstrators to build protest shanties provided the shanties were structurally safe.
The Coalition members for their part
should have publically committed
themselves to paying scrupulous attention to fire and safety laws.
This morning, an impending sequel to
Monday's ignoble events seems to have
been averted. Reason has apparently
triumphed over the brute force tactics used earlier this week.
We can only hope that the latest decision to permit the construction of safe
protest shanties will foreshadow a
climate of cooperation between protestors and the University and prevent
unnecessary and mutually unproductive
hostilities in the future.

To the Editor:
As a third-term member of
the SAC Executive Board and
SAC Secretary, I wish to correct what SAC Chairman
David Shade announced at the
Student Council meeting last
Wednesday as reported by the
News-Letter.
First, the members or the
SAC Executive Board have
never proposed to restrict
posters for private use to one
bulletin board on campus until
David Shade suggested it during the Student Council

position of the Board that

boards be divided with a section

and $5 for each additional one.

at the Board meeting, it was
never voted upon or approved.

posterers on campus, the poster
policy, as passed by the SAC
Executive Board and Student
Council, is as follows:

event is permitted.

clearly marked expiration date.
3. Posters must be affixed
with thumbtacks or tape, not
staples.

assessed for each illegal poster.
This includes both posters that
are not on bulletin boards and
excessive postering on a bulletin
board. The money collected
will go into a fund for purchasing new bulletin boards.

any confusion about the poster
policy. Any suggestions for improving the policy is more than
welcome by the SAC Executive
Board.
